fields: {{c1::Cloud Identity}} is an {{c2::Identity as a Service (IDaaS)}} solution that allows you to {{c3::centrally manage users and groups who can access cloud resources}}
Resource Manager {{c1::Resource Hierarchy}} is made of: {{c2::Organization, Folders, Projects, Service Resources}}
Resource Manager Resources in GCP exist in one of the {{c1::four}} layers of the {{c2::Resource hierarchy}}
Resource Manager Resources can be hosted by {{c1::one}} parent
Resource Manager Resource Manager Resources have an {{c1::IAM policy}} attached to them to define {{c2::permissions}}
Resource Manager Resources inherit the {{c1::IAM policy}} of {{c2::their parent}}
Resource Manager {{c1::Organization}} is a resource type used to represent {{c2::the entire company}}
Resource Manager {{c1::Organization}} resource is {{c2::unique}} in the resource hierarchy
Resource Manager {{c1::Organization}} is at the {{c2::top}} of the {{c3::resource hierarchy}}
IAM {{c1::Members}} defines {{c2::WHO}} get (what) access to (which) cloud resources
Cloud Identity Google account is one of the five {{c1::IAM member type}}
Cloud Identity Service Account is one of the five {{c1::IAM member type}}
Cloud Identity Google group is one of the five {{c1::IAM member type}}
G Suite domain is one of the five {{c1::IAM member type}}
Cloud Identity domain is one of the five {{c1::IAM member type}}
IAM {{c1::Member types}} are: {{c2::Google account, Service Account, Google Group, G Suite Domain, Cloud Identity Domain}}
Cloud Identity {{c1::Google accounts and Service accounts}} are the only IAM member types allowing {{c2::users to authenticate (login/password)}}
Cloud Identity {{c1::Google accounts}} are used by {{c2::people to authenticate and access resources}}
Cloud Identity {{c1::Google accounts}} can be either {{c2::unmanaged (gmail address) or managed (G Suite User)}}
IAM {{c1::Service accounts}} are used by {{c2::machines (application, service, scripts) to authenticate and access resources}}
Cloud Identity {{c1::Google groups}} are collection of {{c2::Google accounts or Service accounts}}
Cloud Identity {{c1::Google groups}} are useful to {{c2::grant permissions once to a collection of individual accounts}}
Cloud Identity {{c1::Google groups}} make it easy to {{c2::add/remove individual accounts from established permissions}}
Resource Manager {{c1::Folder}} is a resource type used to {{c2::organize projects in logical units (e.g department)}}
Resource Manager Folders can also contain {{c1::other folders}} to {{c2::create multi-level folder hierarchy}}
Resource Manager {{c1::Project}} is a resource type used to {{c2::host the service resources}}
Resource Manager {{c1::Projects}} are identified by a {{c2::global unique ID name and ID number}}
Resource Manager {{c1::Resource}} is a resource type used to {{c2::represent the actual GCP service objects (e.g. VMs, buckets, databases)}}
IAM {{c1::Policy}} is a list binding {{c2::members and roles}} to define access to a resource
Resource Manager Resources apply {{c1::the most permissive}} permission when there is a conflict between several policies
Resource Manager {{c1::Organization policies}} are objects used to {{c2::apply constraints to resources and prevent undesired behaviors (e.g. allowing public IPs)}}
Cloud Identity provides a {{c1::Single Sign On (SSO)}} feature to {{c2::login users accross service}}
Cloud Identity {{c1::accounts}} provide identity and authentication for users who {{c2::do not need G Suite apps and licenses}}
Cloud Identity {{c1::Google Group for Business}} provides {{c2::enhanced community feature for forums (groups.google.com)}}
Cloud Identity {{c1::2SV Enforcement}} can {{c2::force users to use a second authentication method at login}}
Cloud Identity {{c2::SSO}} supports out of the box {{c1::more than 200 third party cloud applications}}
Cloud Identity SSO can support non-catalogued third party apps using {{c1::SAML}}
Cloud Identity {{c1::GCDS (Google Cloud Directory Sync)}} is a solution to {{c2::synchronize Active Directory or LDAP domains with Cloud Identity}}
Cloud Identity GCDS {{c1::Rules}} are used to {{c2::configure the synchronization option (user, OU, server)}}
Cloud Identity GCDS Synchronization direction is {{c1::one-way to prevent any destructive operation on the source LDAP}}
Cloud Identity GCDS {{c1::Utility}} is the {{c2::software running the synchronization on the source LDAP server}}
Cloud Identity GCDS Synchronization 1st step is to {{c1::export AD/LDAP data (e.g. users, groups) in a list}}
Cloud Identity GCDS Synchronization 2nd step is to {{c1::export Cloud Identity data (e.g. users, groups, contacts) in a list}}
Cloud Identity GCDS Synchronization 3rd step is to {{c1::compare AD/LDAP and Cloud Identity lists}}
Cloud Identity GCDS Synchronization 4th step is to {{c1::synchronize in Cloud Identity differences and send an email report}}
Cloud Identity Interface is accessed on {{c1::admin.google.com}}
Cloud Identity GCDS configuration require setting source LDAP ({{c1::Domain name, oAuth authorization, LDAP server}})
Cloud Identity GCDS configuration require setting data to sync ({{c1::OU, Users, Groups, Profiles, Schemas, Shared Contacts, Calendar Resources, Licenses}})
Cloud Identity GCDS configuration can be set with {{c1::Search Rules}} to filter objects based on strings
Cloud Identity GCDS configuration can be set with Logging ({{c1::$users\gcds_sync.log, log level}})
Cloud Identity GCDS {{c1::Sync Simulation}} can show the changes before performing them
APIs Activation status needt to {{c1::be enabled in a project}} before they can be used
API Dashboard provides {{c1::performance metrics about requests (Traffic, Errors, Latency)}}
API usage can be analyzed in more details in {{c1::Stackdrive Consumed API resource type}}
IAM Service Account auditing can be done using: {{c1::Console, SDK, Stackdrive Logging}}
KMS Hierarchy starts from: {{c1::Project, Location, Key Ring, Key, Key Version}}
KMS Projects are recommended to be {{c1::separate from resource projects to enforce principle of least privilege}}
KMS Locations are one of three regional scopes: {{c1::Global, Multi-Region (e.g. US), Region (e.g. us-east4)}}
KMS Key Rings are the {{c1::top service resources}} in the KMS Hierarchy
KMS Key Rings are {{c1::logical grouping of one or several keys to manage them together}}
KMS Keys inherit {{c1::permissions from their parent key rings}}
KMS Keys are {{c1::logical resources used to encrypt data for a use case (e.g encrypt all data in a bucket)}}
KMS Key Versions are {{c1::resources containing the cryptographic material actually encrypting the data}}
KMS Key Versions are numbered {{c1::sequentially starting from 1}}
KMS Key Versions have state reflecting their status: {{c1::Enabled, Disabled, Scheduled for destruction, Destroyed}}
KMS Decryption process automatically select {{c1::the right Key Version used to encrypt the data}}
KMS Symmetric Keys {{c1::have}} a Primary Key Version
KMS Asymmetric Keys {{c1::do not have}} a Primary Key Version
KMS Key rings and Keys cannot be {{c1::deleted to avoid name collisions}}
KMS (Key Management Service) is a solution used to {{c1::manage cryptographic keys}}
KMS Envelope Encryption 1st step is to {{c1::generate a DEK (e.g. "openssl genrsa") locally on the machine}}
KMS Envelope Encryption 2nd step is to {{c1::use the DEK to encrypt the data on the machine}}
KMS Envelope Encryption 3rd step is to {{c1::generate a KEK with KMS}}
KMS Envelope Encryption 4th step is to {{c1::encrypt the DEK with the KEK and store the encrypted DEK copy}}
KMS GMEK (Google Managed Encryption Key) is the {{c1::default scheme where data is encrypted at rest}}
KMS CMEK (Customer Managed Encryption Key) is a method where {{c1::keys are stored in KMS but customers control their management and rotation}}
KMS CMEK is available with {{c1::GCE, GCS, BiqQuery, Dataproc, Cloud Build}}
KMS CSEK (Customer Supplied Encryption Key) is a method where {{c1::private keys are stored by customers}}
Encryption at rest is the process of encrypting data when {{c1::it is stored at rest (e.g. objects stored in buckets, disks stored in GCE)}}
Encryption in transit is the process of encrypting data when {{c1::it is transmitted over the network (e.g. HTTPS)}}
Envelope Encryption is a cryptographic method where {{c1::the key encrypting the data (DEK) is encrypted by another key (KEK)}}
DEK (Data Encryption Key) is {{c1::the key managed directly encrypting the data on the storage layer}}
KEK (Key Encryption Key) is {{c1::the logical key encrypting the DEK}}
GCS {{c1::Object Lifecycle Management}} is a feature used to {{c2::change an object state after a period of time}}
Bigquery {{c1::table expiration}} can be set to {{c2::delete tables a number of days after its creation}}
BigTable {{c1::column families}} can be set with an {{c2::expiration date to delete old items}}
The main components of BigQuery are {{c1::Projects, data are hosted in GCP projects}}
VPC {{c1::auto}} mode network can be converted to a {{c2::custom}} mode network
VPC {{c1::custom}} mode network {{c3::cannot be}} converted to a {{c2::auto}} mode network
VPC Service Limit for number of VMs is {{c1::15,000}}
VPC networks {{c1::do not}} support multicast
VPC networks {{c1::do not}} support IPv6 for {{c2::internal IPs}}
{{c1::Cloud Armor}} is solution used to {{c2::protect network resources against Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS)}}
Cloud Armor {{c1::Security Policy}} defines {{c2::rules to filter traffic based on IP for targets}}
Cloud Armor {{c1::Targets}} are non-CDN HTTP(S) Load Balancers used to apply Security Policies
Cloud Amor {{c1::SSL Policies}} are used to {{c2::define how an SSL session is negotiated (Minimum TLS version, Compatibility profile)}}
VPC {{c1::(Virtual Private Cloud)}} is the cloud equivalent of a data center
VPC networks {{c1::do not}} support broadcast
VPC Sharing is a feature used to {{c1::host resources from several projects in a common Shared VPC Network}}
VPC Sharing is useful to separate {{c1::the administration workload of the common networking infrastructure and service resources}}

common networking: VPC, Subnets, Routes, Firewall, Interconnect
service resources: Instances, service configuration
VPC Host Projects are projects {{c1::containing a common Shared VPC Network available to run the service resources}}
VPC Service Projects are projects {{c1::attached to the Host Project to use its Shared VPC Network and subnets}}
VPC Sharing IAM Role Organization Admin is needed to {{c1::grant the Compute Shared VPC Admin role}}
VPC Sharing IAM Role Compute Shared VPC Admin is needed to {{c1::create and manage the Shared VPC Network in the Host Project}}
VPC Sharing IAM Role Compute Network User (aka Service Project Admin) is needed to {{c1::create service resources in a Shared VPC Network of a Host Project}}
VPC Peering is a feature allowing {{c1::resources to communicate using private IP address space (RFC 1918)}}
VPC Peering {{c1::can}} connect networks hosted in different organizations
VPC Peering traffic {{c1::does not}} transit through the public Internet
VPC Peering traffic {{c1::does not}} incur egress bandwidth charges
VPC Peering Service Limit is {{c1::25}} connections per VPC Network
VPC Peering supports traffic for {{c1::GCE, GKE, GAE Flexible}}
VPC Peering network {{c1::cannot}} overlap CIDR ranges
VPC Peering {{c1::does not}} support transitive connection
If 2 peerings exist between VPC A-B and VPC B-C, VPC A-C will not communicate
Load Balancing type HTTP(S) has {{c1::1 use case: External and HTTP/S traffic}}
Load Balancing type SSL Proxy has {{c1::1 use case: External, TCP traffic needing SSL offload}}

Load Balancing type TCP Proxy has {{c1::2 use cases:
External, TCP, non-SSL offload, needing Global or IPv6 AND 
External, TCP, non-SSL offload, non global-IPv6 not need to preserve Client IPs}}

Load Balancing type Network TCP/UDP has {{c1::2 use cases:
External UDP AND
External, TCP, non-SSL offload, non global-IPv6 needing to preserve Client IPs}}
Load Balancing type Internal TCP/UDP has {{c1::1 use case: Internal, TCP/UDP traffic}}
Load Balancing type Internal HTTP(S) has {{c1::1 use case: Internal, HTTP/S traffic}}
Load Balancing Backend is the resource {{c1::representing the internal resources the LB will distribute traffic (GCE Instance Groups, GCS Bucket)}}
Load Balancing Health check is {{c1::a test (TCP/HTTP(S)/SSL) the LB will perform on the backend resources to drain/recreate faulty resources}}
Load Balancing Host and Path Rules determine {{c1::where the traffic will be distributed (e.g. service /user or /cart)}}
Load Balancing Frontend is the {{c1::configuration of the public-facing part (Protocol HTTP/S, Elastic IP)}}
Load Balancing SSL Proxy can be configured with up to {{c1::15 SSL certificates}}
Load Balancing Logs for HTTP request are recorded {{c1::in Stackdriver Logging in the Resource Type Cloud HTTP Load Balancer}}
Load Balancing Monitoring metrics are {{c1::recorded and displayed in Stackdriver}}
Stackdriver Logging Log Streams are either {{c1::Admin Activity, Data Access, System Event}}
Stackdriver Logging Admin Activity log records {{c1::API calls and actions modifying configuration or resource metadata}}
Stackdriver Logging Admin Activity log is {{c1::enabled}} by default
Stackdriver Logging Admin Activity log retention period is {{c1::400 days}}
Stackdriver Logging Data Access log records {{c1::API calls and actions accessing and modifying resource data}}
Stackdriver Logging Data Access log is {{c1::disabled}} by default
Stackdriver Logging Data Access log retention period is {{c1::30 days}}
Stackdriver Logging System Event log retention period is {{c1::400 days}}
[Stackdriver] GCP Service {{c1::Stackdriver Monitoring}} is used to {{c2::track health metrics for resources}}
[Stackdriver] GCP Service {{c1::Stackdriver Logging}} is used to {{c2::store and analyze logs collected from resources}}
[Stackdriver] GCP Service {{c1::Stackdriver Trace}} is used to {{c2::find performance issues in App Engine}}
[Stackdriver] GCP Service {{c1::Stackdriver Debugger}} is used to {{c2::review and investigate code deployed}}
[Stackdriver] Stackdriver features {{c1::does}} support resource monitoring in {{c2::GCP, AWS, On-Premises}} environments
[Stackdriver Monitoring] {{c1::Agent}} is a component running on {{c2::monitored machines}} and used to {{c3::collect more system or application information}}
[Stackdriver] Stackdriver features {{c1::does}} support out of the box third party solutions (Apache, MySQL, RabbitMQ, etc..)
does / does not
[Stackdriver] Logs are grouped and viewed by {{c1::projects}}
[Stackdriver] Service tiers were {{c1::used for pricing but no longer are}}
[Stackdriver] Groups are used to {{c1::bundle together resources by labels or other categories}}
[Stackdriver Logging] GCP Service Stackdriver Logging is used to {{c1::collect, store and visualize information found on system and application logs}}
[Stackdriver Logging] Retention is {{c1::400}} days for admin activity
[Stackdriver Logging] Retention is {{c1::30}} days for any other log
[Stackdriver Logging] Log Admin activity collects information about {{c1::resource creation and management}}
[Stackdriver Logging] Log Admin activity status is {{c1::enabled}} by default
[Stackdriver Logging] Log Data access collects data about {{c1::user activity}}
[Stackdriver Logging] Log export requires the following steps: {{c1::creating a project, filter to select the entries to export, destination and a sink}}
[Stackdriver Logging] Log export can send data to {{c1::Cloud Storage}} for {{c2::long-term storage}}
[Stackdriver Logging] Log export can send data to {{c1::BigQuery}} for {{c2::analysis}}
[Stackdriver Logging] Log export can send data to {{c1::Pub/Sub}} for {{c2::integration with other systems}}
[Stackdriver Error Reporting] GCP Service Stackdriver Error Reporting is used to {{c1::collect and troubleshoot application errors}}
[Stackdriver Error Reporting] Stackdriver Error Reporting integrates with {{c1::App Engine, Compute Engine, Cloud Functions, AWS EC2}}
[Stackdriver Trace] GCP Service Stackdriver Trace is used to {{c1::find latency issues, application slowness and bottlenecks}}
[Stackdriver Trace] Stackdriver Trace status is {{c1::enabled}} by default
[Stackdriver Trace] Reports can be generated when {{c1::there are at least 100 traces available}}
[Stackdriver Debug] GCP Service Stackdriver Debug is used to {{c1::debug application code deployed in real-time}}
[Stackdriver Debug] Stackdriver Debug integrates with {{c1::App Engine and GKE}}
{{c1::Principle of least privilege}} mandates to {{c2::grant a user/resource just enough permission to perform its work}}
Resource Manager {{c1::Super Administrator}} is the {{c2::email address used to create the organization}}
Resource Manager {{c1::Super Administrator}} has permissions on {{c2::every resource in the organization}}
Resource Manager {{c2::Super Administrator}} should not be used for {{c1::day to day activity because of its danger}}
Resource Manager Super Administrator should be protected by {{c1::Multi Factor Authentication (MFA) with physical token}}
Resource Manager Super Administrator logins should be {{c1::monitored with Stackdriver alerts}}
Resource Manager {{c1::Organization Admin Group}} should be created to {{c2::assign organization permissions for day to day management}}
Resource Manager Organization Admin Group should not contain {{c1::super administrator account}}
{{c1::ISO 27017}} is an International Standard defining {{c2::cloud security practices}}
{{c1::BoringSSL}} is a Google maintained fork of {{c2::OpenSSL to provide encryption in transit}}
{{c1::BoringCrypto}} was validated {{c2::FIPS 140-2}} for {{c3::encryption-in-transit and encryption-at-rest}}
IAM Compromised Credentials remediation steps are to {{c1::create a new credential, deploy it to services, revoke the old credential}}
IAM Compromised Credentials usage should be {{c1::monitored in Console Activity Log for anomalies}}
{{c1::ISO 27001}} is an International Standard defining {{c2::organizational computer security practices}}
[Storage] GCP Service {{c1::BigTable}} is used to host NoSQL databases used for analytics

desc:
Deck to to study and review all services in Google Cloud.

The deck currently prepare candidates for the following certification exams:

 - Professional Cloud Security Engineer (PCSE)
name: google-cloud

note_models.name: Cloze
